Description: Fragmentary cast arched sistrum in copper alloy; solid-cast tubular handle ending with flat disc and surmounted by a double Hathor head with broad collar; Hathor's head with traditional curled wig and cow ears and flanked by raised uraeus; uraeus on right bearing the red crown of Egypt and the one to the left wearing the white crown; grooved socket on top of the capital with figure of a seated cat in the middle; fine incised details on wig and broad collar; arched frame of sistrum missing; maybe offered as a votive offering; corroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This sacred musical instrument was particularly associated to the cult of Egyptian goddesses, notably Hathor, Isis, Bastet or Sekhmet (on sistra, see esp.: Hickmann 1949, p. 76-103, pl. XLV-LXX ; Pinch 1993, p. 143-146 ; Ziegler 1979, p. 31-62 ; Ziegler 1984). Naukratis provided several examples of sistra, in copper alloy like for this specimen, but also in glazed composition. Some of them can be dated to the 26th dynasty, supporting the practice of Egyptian cult activities in this period (Yoyotte 1994-95, 674; Masson forthcoming). Bronze sistra with a middle part consisting of a head of Hathor framed by two uraei are very common (from Herakleion Thonis: Goddio and Fabre 2008, 334, no. 288). The cat below the arched frame (frame missing here) represents the lioness Sekhmet propitiated and transformed in a peaceful cat by the sistrum (for similar examples, see e.g.: Hickmann 1949, CG no. 69305, 69308-69310, 69328; Ziegler 1979, no. 68-75). It belongs to a series of sistra which are difficult to date, possibly during the Late Period (Ziegler 1979, 37). Goddio, F. and Fabre D. 2008 (eds), Egypt’s sunken treasures, Munich.
